title-group.article-title: Single molecule imaging of transcription dynamics, RNA localization and fate in T cells

abstract.p: T cells are critical effector cells against infections and malignancies. To achieve this, they produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IFN-γ and TNF. Cytokine production is a tightly regulated process. The relative contribution of transcriptional and post-transcriptional regulation to mRNA expression is, however, unknown. We therefore implemented single-molecule FISH for primary human T cells (T-cell smFISH) to simultaneously quantify nascent RNA, mature mRNA levels and its localization with single-cell resolution. T-cell smFISH uncovered heterogeneous cytokine mRNA levels, with high cytokine producers displaying dual IFNG/TNF RNA transcription activity. Throughout activation, nuclear cytokine mRNAs accumulated, whereas cytoplasmic cytokine mRNA was degraded through translation-dependent decay. Lastly, T-cell smFISH uncovered cytokine-specific regulation by the RNA-binding protein HuR. Thus, T-cell smFISH provides novel insights in the intricate (post)-transcriptional processes in T cells.

body.p: CD8+ T cells play a crucial role in clearing infected and malignant cells. Upon target cell recognition, effector CD8+ T cells undergo a substantial remodelling of their transcriptome and proteome (1–4). This remodelling allows for the rapid release of effector molecules such as granzymes and pro-inflammatory cytokines (5, 6). Key pro-inflammatory cytokines are IFN-γ and TNF, which license T cells to kill their target cells (7–9).

Cytokine production is regulated at multiple molecular levels, including transcriptional and epigenetic mechanisms (10, 11). Another important layer of gene expression control is post- transcriptional regulation (PTR), processes including - but not restricted to - RNA splicing, RNA transport, RNA stability, and translation control. The importance of PTR is evidenced by the fact that measured mRNA levels in T cells only mildly correlate with protein abundance (4), a highly conserved feature throughout evolution (12). For instance, antigen-experienced T cells contain ready-to-deploy cytokine mRNA, which is blocked through translational control, yet released from this block to serve as template for translation for rapid recall responses (13). Provided that cytokine overproduction induces immunopathology and autoimmunity, and that loss of production results in dysfunctional anti-tumor responses (8, 14), it is of most importance to decipher how PTR processes control T cell function.

RNA binding proteins (RBPs) are key mediators of PTR that define the abundance of mRNA and protein in T cells (6, 15, 16). For instance, the RBP ELAVL1/HuR promotes early cytokine production of activated human CD8+ T cells (6). In other cell types, HuR was shown to mediate pre-mRNA splicing, control poly-adenylation, regulate the nuclear export, and when located in the cytoplasm, promote mRNA stability and translation (17–21). Provided that RBP expression and their mode of action is cell-type specific (22, 23), it remains to be uncovered how HuR promotes cytokine production in T cells.

The fate of an mRNA molecule is regulated at specific subcellular locations (24). In the nucleus RNA is transcribed, spliced, and modified. When translocated into the cytoplasm, translation can take place. Previous studies studying the life of mRNAs in T cells measured mRNA transcription, mRNA kinetics, and their subcellular localization by bulk RNA-sequencing (25, 26). However, these studies lack single-cell resolution, which is pivotal when studying intrinsically highly heterogeneous T cell responses. Single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization (smFISH) provides such in-depth insights (27, 28). smFISH can visualize and quantify nascent cytokine mRNA at transcription sites, quantify mature mRNA and identify its subcellular localization, with single-cell resolution. Studies using smFISH in T cells (29, 30) employed standard smFISH pipelines that were developed for adherent cells (31, 32). Because these pipelines are not geared towards the small cell size and round morphology of T cells, they fail to unequivocally call the subcellular localization of transcripts. To overcome this limitation, we developed T-cell smFISH, a new analysis pipeline that precisely localizes nuclear and cytoplasmic mRNA for the investigation of (post)-transcriptional mechanisms in T cells. Using this pipeline, we achieved unprecedented depth of analyzing the fate of mRNA in T cells, here exemplified for cytokine mRNAs.

sec.title: Quantifying cytokine mRNA in primary T cells with 3D single-molecule resolution
sec.p: To quantify cytokine mRNAs in human T cells, we first optimized the smFISH hybridization and analysis protocol (see Materials and Methods). We generated effector T cells (Teff) that can rapidly respond to recall responses, by activating human blood-derived CD8+ T cells for 72 h with α-CD3/α-CD28, followed by a 7-day of rest. Teff cells were subsequently restimulated with α-CD3/α-CD28, fixed, and simultaneously probed for IFNG and TNF mRNA by two-color smFISH (Fig 1A) (28, 33). Z-stacks were acquired every 200 nm with a high-numerical aperture objective coupled to a wide-field fluorescence microscope to encompass the entire cell thickness, and to precisely identify the x, y, z position of an mRNA (34). T cell shape and outline were deduced from auto-fluorescence in the probe channel and from differential interference contrast images (DIC; Suppl. Fig. 1A). DAPI was used for nuclear staining (Suppl. Fig. 1A). To accommodate for the small and compact structure of T cells, T-cell smFISH pipeline was developed to localize individual cytokine mRNA molecules with subcellular resolution, by combining FISH-quant (32) for RNA quantification, filtering for cell selection, and Cell-Pose (35) for 3D mask reconstruction (Suppl. Fig. 1B, Movie S1-S2; https://github.com/nikolinasostaric/T-cell_smFISH). The T-cell smFISH pipeline achieved 98% accuracy, as defined by manual analysis of 100 randomly chosen mRNAs. T-cell smFISH thus allowed us to elucidate the expression of cytokine transcripts upon T cell activation with single-cell and subcellular resolution.

sec.title: T-cell smFISH uncovers cytokine-specific transcription activity
sec.p: Having established T-cell smFISH, we studied the cytokine mRNA dynamics during T cell activation with α-CD3/α-CD28. The key effector cytokines IFN-γ and TNF are produced early after T cell activation, yet with distinct kinetics (36, 37). To uncover the underlying mechanism, we measured nascent RNA and the subcellular distribution of mature mRNA (Fig. 1C), and we compared that to cytokine protein levels.

We first focused on nascent cytokine RNAs. Resting Teff cells (t=0h) were devoid of active transcription sites (TsX) for IFNG (Fig. 1D, Suppl. Fig. 1C). At 1 h of activation, however, 2% Teff cells expressed nascent IFNG mRNA with a median of 12 nascent RNAs per TsX (Fig. 1D; Suppl. Fig. 1C-1D). At 3 h of activation, active TsX peaked with 8%, with a median of 3 nascent IFNG RNAs per TsX, and this level of nascent RNA was maintained up to 6 h of activation (Fig. 1D, Suppl. Fig. 1C-1D). Of note, even though at 1 h of activation we observed bi-allelic transcription in 45% of the IFNG-transcribing cells, at later time points monoallelic IFNG transcription dominated (Suppl. Fig. 1C).

In contrast to IFNG, nascent TNF RNA is already detected in 1% of resting Teff cells with a median of 5 nascent RNA molecules per TsX (Fig. 1D, Suppl. Fig. 1C-1D). At 1h of stimulation, nascent TNF peaked with 13 nascent RNA per TsX, and dropped and stabilized at 2h with 6 molecules on average per cell (Fig. 1D, Suppl. Fig. 1C-1D). Intriguingly, this drop did not result from fewer active TsX for TNF. Furthermore, bi-allelic transcription was observed in 56% of the TNF-transcribing cells until 3 h of activation, and mono-allelic transcription was only more prevalent at later time points (Suppl. Fig. 1C). Thus, nascent IFNG and TNF RNA display different kinetics, with IFNG requiring T cell activation for de novo synthesis, and TNF already being active in resting Teff cells. IFNG transcription relies more on mono-allelic transcription, whereas TNF transcription also employs bi-allelic synthesis during early T cell activation.

sec.title: Cytokine-specific kinetics of mRNA and protein expression during T cell activation
sec.p: We next quantified mature TNF and IFNG mRNA. Even though nascent IFNG RNA was undetectable in resting Teff cells, 36% expressed low but detectable levels of mature IFNG mRNA, and 28% expressed mature TNF mRNA (each a median of 1 molecule/cell; Fig.1E, Suppl. Fig. 1E). At 1 h of stimulation, 77% T cells expressed mature IFNG and 74% expressed TNF mRNA (median of 4 and 13 molecules/cell, respectively; Suppl. Fig. 1E-F). Notably, with 1-200 IFNG and TNF mRNA molecules/cell, a high inter-cellular variability was observed in all three donors, at all time points measured (Fig. 1E; Suppl. Fig. 1F). Yet, whereas a subset of Teff cells maintained high levels of mature IFNG mRNA throughout T cell activation (>100 molecules/cell; Fig 1E), the levels of mature TNF mRNA rapidly declined below 100 molecules/cell from 2 h of activation onwards (Fig. 1E).

Also the cytokine production displayed high intercellular and inter-donor heterogeneity (Fig. 1F). Following the expression patterns of mature mRNA, IFN-γ protein production peaked at 2 h of activation with a maximum of 10% of Teff cells and remained stable thereafter (Fig. 1F). Yet, IFN-γ protein levels per cell showed high inter-cellular variability and peaked at 4h post stimulation, as defined by median fluorescence intensity (Fig. 1G). Conversely, and in line with higher mature TNF mRNA levels at 1h of activation (Fig. 1E), TNF protein production peaked at 2-3 h of activation with 12% TNF-producing Teff cells, and rapidly declined thereafter (Fig. 1F). Yet, the protein production per cell remained constant throughout (Fig.1G). Combined, these data show that the protein production kinetics of IFN-γ and TNF follow the cytokine mRNA kinetics.

sec.title: Dual cytokine mRNA-expressing Teff cells dominate the immune response
sec.p: Dual cytokine producers are more potent effector T cells than single cytokine producers (37, 38). We therefore questioned how single (SP) and double positive (DP) cytokine mRNA expressors (Movie S1) contribute to the observed high variability of cytokine mRNA expression. The number of nascent IFNG RNA per TsX was higher in DP Teff cells, but not of the nascent TNF (Fig. 2A). Yet, the percentage of active TsX was substantially higher in DP cytokine RNA-expressing Teff cells, which was observed at all time points (Suppl. Fig. 2A). In addition, DP T cells displayed more bi-allelic transcription for both cytokines (Suppl. Fig. 2A). Higher transcriptional activity in DP T cells also resulted in more mature cytokine mRNA (Fig. 2B, C). Upon T cell activation DP T cells expressed substantially higher percentages and numbers of mature IFNG mRNA/cell at all time points measured and mature TNF mRNA at early T cell activation time points (1-3 h) compared to SP T cells (Fig. 2B, C). Not only mRNA, but also the percentage of protein-producing Teff and protein production/cell was higher in DP cytokine producers (Fig. 2D, Suppl. Fig. 2B). In conclusion, Teff cells with active TsX for both IFNG and TNF contain more mature cytokine mRNA. Furthermore, DP cytokine producers dominate the cytokine production kinetics upon T cell activation and contribute to the observed high inter-cellular heterogeneity of cytokine production.

sec.title: Differential subcellular distribution of IFNG and TNF mRNA
sec.p: Mature mRNA can only serve as template for translation when located in the cytoplasm. Therefore, we next investigated the subcellular distribution of IFNG and TNF mRNA during activation with T-cell smFISH (Suppl. Fig. 3A). In resting Teff cells, the vast majority of the little mature IFNG mRNA and TNF mRNA present was in the nucleus (Fig. 3A, Suppl. Fig. 3A - top panel). However, T cell activation rapidly shifted the distribution of mature IFNG mRNA to the cytoplasm (Fig. 3A). Yet, from 2 h of activation onwards, the IFNG mRNA was equally distributed between nucleus and cytoplasm (Fig. 3A). TNF mRNA was more prevalent in the nucleus throughout and was with 75% most apparent at the peak of its expression, i.e. at 1 h of T cell activation (Fig. 3A, Suppl. Fig. 3A). Thus, mature IFNG and TNF mRNAs differentially distribute between nucleus and cytoplasm in activated Teff cells.

sec.title: Translation-dependent decay controls cytokine mRNA levels upon T cell activation
sec.p: The unexpectedly high levels of mature cytokine mRNA in the nucleus prompted us to question how de novo transcription and translation contributed to the subcellular distribution. We therefore activated Teff cells for 2h and in the 2nd blocked de novo transcription with Actinomycin D (ActD) or translation with Harringtonine (Harr) (Fig. 3B). As expected, Harr treatment reduced both the overall translation as defined by puromycin incorporation, and the cytokine production (Suppl. Fig. 3B, C). Likewise, T-cell smFISH analysis showed that ActD almost completely blocked the presence of nascent RNA (Fig. 3C). ActD treatment also reduced the numbers of measured mature IFNG mRNA molecules/cell by 5-fold (Fig. 3D). Intriguingly, mature TNF mRNA expression was much less affected by ActD treatment (Fig. 3D), indicating that the production boost of TNF mRNA during the first hour of T cell activation (Fig. 1E) suffices to maintain high levels of mature TNF mRNA expression during the 2nd hour of activation.

Notably, blocking translation with Harr increased the numbers of mature cytokine mRNA/cell compared to control (Fig. 3D), indicating a feedback mechanism from translation to the overall mRNA expression. T-cell smFISH analysis uncovered that Harr treatment primarily increased the cytoplasmic IFNG mRNA and TNF mRNA (Fig. 3E). To determine whether this cytoplasmic accumulation upon Harr treatment resulted from translation-dependent mRNA decay, we simultaneously blocked translation and transcription and measured cytokine mRNA by qRT-PCR. ActD treatment alone reduced the overall cytokine mRNA levels by 60% compared to control (Fig. 3F), however, this reduction had little effect on the protein output (Suppl. Fig. 3D, E). In contrast, ActD/Harr treatment combined substantially reduced the protein production (Suppl. Fig. 3D, E). Yet, the expression levels for IFNG and TNF mRNA increased by 30% in ActD/Harr-treated Teff cells compared to Act treatment alone, and this increase was not observed for IL2 mRNA (Fig. 3F). Combined, the T-cell smFISH pipeline uncovered with single-cell resolution that translation regulates the cytoplasmic IFNG and TNF mRNA levels. Furthermore, IFNG and TNF mRNA - but not IL2 mRNA- are subject to translation-dependent decay.

sec.title: HuR differentially controls IFNG and TNF mRNA expression and cytokine production
sec.p: Having established the cytokine mRNA expression kinetics and distribution in Teff cells, we questioned how RNA-binding proteins such as HuR regulate the fate of cytokine mRNA. HuR protein expression increased during the 2 h of T cell activation, however, HuR interacted with IFNG and TNF mRNA only at 1 h post-stimulation, and not at 2h post-stimulation, as determined by RNA-immunoprecipitation (RIP)-qRT-PCR (Suppl. Fig. 4 A, B). To study its role on cytokines, we depleted HuR from Teff cells by CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing (Suppl. Fig. 4C). As previously reported (6), HuR-KO Teff produced less IFN-γ and TNF protein during the first 2h of activation, both in terms of percentage and protein production/cell (Fig. 4A-B). Notably, without resulting in detectable protein production, T-cell smFISH analysis uncovered opposite effects on mRNA levels (Fig. 4C-4D). Resting HuR-KO Teff cells already contained more IFNG mRNA expressing cells (Suppl. Fig. 4D), and the median mRNA molecules/cell increased from 3 to 10 for IFNG, and from 5 to 9 for TNF (Fig. 4D). At 1h of stimulation, the percentage of mRNA-expressing Teff cells and number of cytokine molecules/cell was also higher in HuR-KO (Fig. 4D, Suppl. Fig. 4D). Only at 2 h activation, numbers of cytokine mRNAs/cell dropped below those of control Teff cells (Fig. 4D).

To determine whether the higher cytokine mRNA levels observed in HuR-KO Teff cells resulted from increased transcription, we studied the number of nascent RNA. Resting HuR-KO Teff cells contained 8 nascent IFNG RNA/cell compared to 5 nascent IFNG RNA/cell in control T cells, and this slight increase was lost by 2h post activation (Fig. 4E). In contrast, nascent TNF RNA remained unaffected by HuR depletion at all time points (Fig. 4E). Thus, despite that HuR-KO T cells produce less cytokine during early activation, mature mRNAs accumulate, and transcription may only partly contribute to this accumulation.

sec.title: HuR deletion affects the cellular distribution of IFNG and TNF mRNA
sec.p: Because higher cytokine mRNA levels in HuR-KO cells did not result in higher but lower protein production, we questioned whether HuR depletion affected the subcellular mRNA distribution. T-cell smFISH analysis uncovered that resting HuR-KO Teff cells expressed significantly more cytoplasmic IFNG and TNF mRNA molecules than control Teff cells (Fig. 5A). HuR-KO Teff cells also contained slightly more nuclear TNF mRNA (Fig. 5A). Upon 1h activation, both cytokine mRNAs were slightly increased in both subcellular compartments, which was reversed at 2 h of T cell activation (Fig. 5A). When we determined the relative distribution of cytokine mRNA within each individual Teff cell, we found that resting HuR-KO T cells contain more IFNG mRNA in the cytoplasm, which drops at 1h but is reverted at 2h post-stimulation (Fig. 5B). In contrast, TNF mRNA is slightly more nuclear at 0h and 1h activation in HuR-KO cells compared to control cells, and this effect is lost at 2h activation when HuR also loses its interaction with cytokine mRNAs (Fig. 5B, Suppl. Fig. 4B). Hence, HuR deletion influences the subcellular localization of cytokine mRNAs in a time-dependent manner.

sec.title: HuR regulates the polyadenylation of TNF mRNA
sec.p: Lastly, we aimed to decipher how HuR regulates cytokine RNA. HuR can stabilize its target mRNAs (39, 40). However, measuring mRNA decay in T cells activated for 1h, and then treated for an additional 1-2h with ActD showed no differences in overall mRNA levels or RNA decay rates between HuR-KO and control Teff cells (Fig. 5C). Thus, HuR does not appear to regulate cytokine mRNA stability.

HuR can act as splicing factor (18, 41). Yet, irrespective of the nuclear IFNG mRNA accumulation (Fig. 5B), no overt differences of intron-exon junctions were found between HuR-KO and control Teff cells (Suppl. Fig. 5A). Additionally, even though splicing is considered a key event for TNF (42, 43), HuR deletion has only limited- if any- effect on TNF splicing (Suppl. Fig. 5A), indicating that HuR is not essential for IFNG and TNF RNA splicing in T cells.

HuR can also regulate polyadenylation (17, 20). However, we found no changes in the poly(A) tail profile of IFNG mRNA in HuR KO cells at 1h of T cell activation (Fig 5D, Suppl. Fig 5B). In sharp contrast, HuR deficiency substantially impaired the poly(A) tail of TNF mRNA (Fig 5D, Suppl. Fig 5B). Thus, HuR employs cytokine-specific regulatory mechanisms to control the fate of mRNA, and ultimately the protein expression of these two key pro-inflammatory cytokines.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we present the T-cell smFISH pipeline to simultaneously quantify nascent and mature cytokine mRNAs and their subcellular distribution. Importantly, this three-dimensional analysis of RNA expression with single-molecule and single-cell resolution can provide unprecedented insights in the regulation of cytokine production and the activity of RNA binding proteins in T cells, as we showcased for HuR.

Even though most activated Teff cells express cytokine mRNAs, they display a two order of magnitude difference in mRNA and protein expression. Within the highly heterogenous T cell responses, cytokine production upon T cell activation primarily originates from Teff cells that transcribe both cytokine mRNAs simultaneously, suggesting that this superior cytokine production by DP cells is cell-intrinsic. Whereas the underlying mechanism is yet to be uncovered, it is tempting to speculate that DP cells produce more cytokines because of 1) an open chromatin structure at the cytokine loci or their respective regulators, 2) high expression of cytokine-driving transcription factors, or 3) more responsive signaling cascades in response to T cell activation. T-cell smFISH may help uncover the underlying mechanisms.

The subcellular localization of cytokine mRNA dictates the amount of cytokine production. Indeed, T-cell smFISH uncovered that nuclear accumulation of IFNG and TNF mRNA, suggesting that nuclear retention (44) regulates the availability of cytokine mRNAs for translation. In addition, nuclear retention of TNF mRNA may support its efficient splicing as previously suggested (42, 43). We here uncovered that translation-dependent decay (45) contributes to the lower cytoplasmic mRNA levels we measured, a feature that appeared transcript-specific, as IL2 mRNA was resistant.

T-cell smFISH also provides novel insights in the mode of action of RBPs. HuR deficiency resulted in increased levels of IFNG and TNF mRNA, yet with lower protein production. Of note, smFISH probes can detect mature and pre-spliced RNA (27, 32). However, splicing was not affected in HuR KO T cells. Intriguingly, T-cell smFISH revealed cytokine-specific regulation. HuR deficiency slightly altered the transcription of IFNG mRNA, but not that of TNF mRNA. In turn, HuR is required for the polyadenylation of TNF, but not of IFNG. Polyadenylation can modulate mRNA stability (46), but mRNA stability was not altered for TNF. HuR can also promote alternative poly-adenylation and compete with the PolyA cleavage factor (17, 47). Whether this induces the observed impaired translation of TNF is however yet to be determined. IFNG mRNA does not depend on HuR for splicing or polyadenylation. Therefore, HuR may regulate the nuclear export of IFNG mRNA during early T cell activation, as previously described for other target mRNAs (48, 49). Irrespective of its exact mode of action on IFNG mRNA, our data highlight that HuR’s activity is target-specific, as was previously reported for other RBPs (23, 50).

In summary, T-cell smFISH is a sensitive and quantitative tool with single-cell, single- molecule resolution for deciphering post-transcriptional regulation. We uncovered that differential mechanisms govern IFNG and TNF mRNA kinetics and showcased the contribution of HuR in regulating T cell effector function. We propose T-cell smFISH as a powerful tool to uncover molecular mechanisms underlying dysregulated cytokine production, such as impaired production upon chronic stimulation (51) or excessive production in immunopathology (14, 52, 53). The custom-made T-cell smFISH pipeline we present here should support further studies on RNA expression and RBP-mediated regulation that define T cell function.
